space_objectÂ¶

Defines a space object. Encapsulates orbital elements, propagation and related methods.

Example:

Using space object for propagation.

import numpy as n
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import SpaceObject as so
import plothelp

o = so.SpaceObject(
    a=7000, e=0.0, i=69,
    raan=0, aop=0, mu0=0,
    C_D=2.3, A=1.0, m=1.0,
    C_R=1.0, oid=42,
    mjd0=57125.7729,
)

t=n.linspace(0,24*3600,num=1000, dtype=n.float)
ecefs=o.get_state(t)

fig = plt.figure(figsize=(15,15))
ax = fig.add_subplot(111, projection='3d')
ax.view_init(15, 5)
plothelp.draw_earth_grid(ax)

ax.plot(ecefs[0,:],ecefs[1,:],ecefs[2,:],'-',alpha=0.5,color="black")
plt.title("Orbital propagation test")
plt.show()

Using space object with a different propagator.

import numpy as n
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import SpaceObject as so
import plothelp
from propagator_orekit import PropagatorOrekit

o = so.SpaceObject(
    a=7000, e=0.0, i=69,
    raan=0, aop=0, mu0=0,
    C_D=2.3, A=1.0, m=1.0,
    C_R=1.0, oid=42,
    mjd0=57125.7729,
    propagator = PropagatorOrekit,
    propagator_options = {
        'in_frame': 'TEME',
        'out_frame': 'ITRF',
    },
)

t=n.linspace(0,24*3600,num=1000, dtype=n.float)
ecefs=o.get_state(t)

fig = plt.figure(figsize=(15,15))
ax = fig.add_subplot(111, projection='3d')
ax.view_init(15, 5)
plothelp.draw_earth_grid(ax)

ax.plot(ecefs[0,:],ecefs[1,:],ecefs[2,:],'-',alpha=0.5,color="black")
plt.title("Orbital propagation test")
plt.show()
space_object.M_e = 5.972e+24Â¶

float: Mass of the Earth

space_object.R_E = 6371000.0Â¶

float: Radius of the Earth

class space_object.SpaceObject(a, e, i, raan, aop, mu0, d=0.01, C_D=2.3, A=1.0, m=1.0, mjd0=57125.7729, oid=42, M_cent=5.972e+24, C_R=1.0, propagator=<class 'propagator_sgp4.PropagatorSGP4'>, propagator_options={}, **kwargs)[source]Â¶

Bases: object

Encapsulates a object in space whoâs dynamics is governed in time by a propagator.

The relation between the Cartesian and Kepler states are a direct transformation according to the below orientation rules. If the Kepler elements are given in a Inertial system, to reference the Cartesian to a Earth-fixed system a earth rotation transformation must be applied externally of the method.

Orientation of the ellipse in the coordinate system:
  • For zero inclination \(i\): the ellipse is located in the x-y plane.
  • The direction of motion as True anoamly \(\nu\): increases for a zero inclination \(i\): orbit is anti-coockwise, i.e. from +x towards +y.
  • If the eccentricity \(e\): is increased, the periapsis will lie in +x direction.
  • If the inclination \(i\): is increased, the ellipse will rotate around the x-axis, so that +y is rotated toward +z.
  • An increase in Longitude of ascending node \(\Omega\): corresponds to a rotation around the z-axis so that +x is rotated toward +y.
  • Changing argument of perihelion \(\omega\): will not change the plane of the orbit, it will rotate the orbit in the plane.
  • The periapsis is shifted in the direction of motion.
  • True anomaly measures from the +x axis, i.e \(\nu = 0\) is located at periapsis and \(\nu = \pi\) at apoapsis.
  • All anomalies and orientation angles reach between 0 and \(2\pi\)

Reference: âOrbital Motionâ by A.E. Roy.

Variables:
  • \(a\): Semi-major axis
  • \(e\): Eccentricity
  • \(i\): Inclination
  • \(\omega\): Argument of perihelion
  • \(\Omega\): Longitude of ascending node
  • \(\nu\): True anoamly
Uses:
  • kep2cart()
  • cart2kep()
  • mean2true()
  • true2mean()
  • rot_mat_z()
  • gmst()
  • write_oem()
Variables:
  • a (float) â Semi-major axis [km]
  • e (float) â Eccentricity
  • i (float) â Inclination [deg]
  • aop (float) â Argument of periapsis [deg]
  • raan (float) â Right ascension of the ascending node [deg]
  • mu0 (float) â Mean anomaly [deg]
  • x (float) â X position [km]
  • y (float) â Y position [km]
  • z (float) â Z position [km]
  • vx (float) â X-direction velocity [km/s]
  • vy (float) â Y-direction velocity [km/s]
  • vz (float) â Z-direction velocity [km/s]
  • oid (int) â Identifying object ID
  • C_D (float) â Drag coefficient
  • C_R (float) â Radiation pressure coefficient
  • A (float) â Area [\(m^2\)]
  • m (float) â Mass [kg]
  • mjd0 (float) â Epoch for state [BC-relative JD]
  • prop (float) â Propagator instance, child of PropagatorBase
  • d (float) â Diameter [m]
  • M_cent (float) â Mass of central body [kg]
  • state_cart (numpy.ndarray) â 6-D vector containing the Cartesian state vector.
  • propagator_options (dict) â Propagator initialization keyword arguments
  • kwargs (dict) â All additional keyword arguments will be passed to the propagator call.

The constructor creates a space object using Kepler elements.

Parameters:
  • a (float) â Semi-major axis in km
  • e (float) â Eccentricity
  • i (float) â Inclination in degrees
  • aop (float) â Argument of perigee in degrees
  • raan (float) â Right ascension of the ascending node in degrees
  • mu0 (float) â Mean anomaly in degrees
  • C_D (float) â Drag coefficient
  • C_R (float) â Radiation pressure coefficient
  • A (float) â Area in square meters
  • m (float) â Mass in kg
  • mjd0 (float) â Epoch for state
  • oid (int) â Identifying object ID
  • d (float) â Diameter in meters
  • M_cent (float) â Mass of central body
  • propagator (PropagatorBase) â Propagator class pointer
  • propagator_options (dict) â Propagator initialization keyword arguments
  • kwargs (dict) â All additional keyword arguments will be passed to the propagator call.
classmethod cartesian(x, y, z, vx, vy, vz, d=0.01, C_D=2.3, A=1.0, m=1.0, mjd0=57125.7729, oid=42, M_cent=5.972e+24, C_R=1.0, propagator=<class 'propagator_sgp4.PropagatorSGP4'>, propagator_options={}, **kwargs)[source]Â¶

Creates a space object using Cartesian elements.

Parameters:
  • x (float) â X position in km
  • y (float) â Y position in km
  • z (float) â Z position in km
  • vx (float) â X-direction velocity in km/s
  • vy (float) â Y-direction velocity in km/s
  • vz (float) â Z-direction velocity in km/s

copy()[source]Â¶

Returns a copy of the SpaceObject instance.

diamÂ¶
get_orbit(t)[source]Â¶

Gets ECEF position at specified times using propagator instance.

Parameters:t (float/list/numpy.ndarray) â Time relative epoch in seconds.
Returns:Array of positions as a function of time.
Return type:numpy.ndarray of size (3,len(t))
get_state(t)[source]Â¶

Gets ECEF state at specified times using propagator instance.

Parameters:t (float/list/numpy.ndarray) â Time relative epoch in seconds.
Returns:Array of state (position and velocity) as a function of time.
Return type:numpy.ndarray of size (6,len(t))
propagate(dt, frame_transformation, frame_options={})[source]Â¶

Propagate and change the epoch of this space object

Frame transformations available:
  • TEME: From ITRF to TEME
  • ITRF: From TEME to ITRF
  • None: Do not perform transformation
  • function pointer: use custom transformation function that takes state as first argument (in SI units) and keyword arguments
update(**kwargs)[source]Â¶

Updates the orbital elements and Cartesian state vector of the space object.

Can update any of the related state parameters, all others will automatically update.

Cannot update Keplerian and Cartesian elements simultaneously.

Parameters:
  • a (float) â Semi-major axis in km
  • e (float) â Eccentricity
  • i (float) â Inclination in degrees
  • aop (float) â Argument of perigee in degrees
  • raan (float) â Right ascension of the ascending node in degrees
  • mu0 (float) â Mean anomaly in degrees
  • x (float) â X position in km
  • y (float) â Y position in km
  • z (float) â Z position in km
  • vx (float) â X-direction velocity in km/s
  • vy (float) â Y-direction velocity in km/s
  • vz (float) â Z-direction velocity in km/s
write_oem(t0, t1, n_items, fname)[source]Â¶

Writes OEM format file of orbital state for specific time interval. The states are linearly spaced in the specified time interval.

Parameters:
  • t0 (float) â Start time.
  • t1 (float) â End time.
  • n_items (int) â State points between start and end times.
